Situation1: Assisting at a traffic accident scene to ensure safety and order
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: The flashing lights of my patrol car reflected off the rain-slicked pavement as I directed traffic around the accident. My radio crackled with updates, and I could see the anxious faces of the drivers, waiting for me to wave them through. As a police officer, I knew my duty was to keep everyone safe, to make sure the scene was secure and that no one else got hurt. But as I glanced at my watch, my heart sank. I was supposed to be across town in ten minutes, unlocking the doors to the community center where a line of people—some elderly, some with children—would already be waiting for the food pantry to open. I was the only volunteer scheduled this morning. I could picture their disappointment, their frustration if I didn’t show up on time. The weight of both uniforms pressed down on me, the badge on my chest and the volunteer lanyard in my bag, each demanding my presence, each expecting me to put them first. I stood in the rain, torn, as the minutes ticked by.
